breaking_news.title: UNC2814 APT Leverages Google Sheets for Global Espionage Across 42 Countries
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Google, in collaboration with industry partners, disrupted UNC2814, a suspected China-linked APT group, after it compromised at least 53 organizations across 42 countries. The group primarily targeted telecommunications and government entities in the Americas, Asia, and Africa. Attackers used SaaS API calls to mask malicious traffic and abused Google Sheets as part of their exploit chain—leveraging spreadsheet functionality to execute commands and evade detection.

Paragraph 2: The campaign demonstrates the growing trend of APTs weaponizing legitimate cloud services to bypass traditional security controls. Organizations in critical sectors, including telecom infrastructure, face heightened risk as attackers exploit trust in SaaS platforms. The disruption is significant, but the group’s persistence and use of infrastructure abuse suggest continued threat activity.

breaking_news.title: Critical Zero-Day in Cisco SD-WAN Actively Exploited Since 2023
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Cisco disclosed that a critical authentication bypass vulnerability (CVE-2026-20127) in its Catalyst SD-WAN solution was actively exploited in zero-day attacks since at least 2023. Attackers leveraged the flaw to compromise SD-WAN controllers and inject rogue peers into targeted networks, enabling persistent access and lateral movement across enterprise infrastructure.

Paragraph 2: The vulnerability affects enterprise networks globally, particularly those using Cisco’s SD-WAN for critical branch and data center connectivity. Active exploitation over multiple years indicates long-term compromise potential for unpatched deployments. Organizations relying on Cisco SD-WAN for secure network segmentation are at severe risk of data exfiltration and service disruption.

breaking_news.title: Claude Code Flaws Enable Remote Code Execution via Untrusted Repos
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Check Point Research and multiple outlets revealed critical vulnerabilities (CVE-2025-59536 and CVE-2026-21852) in Anthropic’s Claude Code AI coding assistant. Attackers can trigger remote code execution and API key theft simply by users cloning and opening malicious repositories—exploiting Hooks, MCP servers, and environment variables to inject and execute arbitrary shell commands.

Paragraph 2: The flaws affect developers globally who use Claude Code in enterprise and open-source workflows. Because the attack chain begins at project initialization, even trusted internal repositories can become compromised if seeded with malicious config files. This represents a paradigm shift in supply chain risk, where AI-assisted development tools themselves become attack vectors.

breaking_news.title: Lazarus APT Deploys Medusa Ransomware in Healthcare and Middle East Attacks
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: North Korea’s Lazarus Group has been observed deploying the Medusa ransomware-as-a-service in attacks against a U.S. healthcare organization and an unnamed Middle Eastern entity. Researchers from Symantec and Carbon Black confirmed the group’s use of Medusa—a shift from its traditional Maui and Play ransomware—indicating a strategic expansion toward financially motivated operations while retaining espionage objectives.

Paragraph 2: The inclusion of Medusa, operated by the Spearwing group, signals Lazarus’s growing hybrid threat posture: blending nation-state espionage with cybercrime monetization. Healthcare and critical infrastructure sectors are especially vulnerable, as ransomware attacks can directly impact patient safety and operational continuity. The campaign underscores the evolving convergence of APT and cybercrime tradecraft.

breaking_news.title: ShinyHunters Breaches CarGurus, Exposing 12.4 Million User Records
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: The ShinyHunters extortion group leaked data from over 12.4 million CarGurus accounts after a failed ransomware extortion attempt. The stolen dataset includes names, emails, phone numbers, addresses, IP addresses, and auto finance application results. CarGurus, a major U.S.-based automotive marketplace, confirmed the breach and is offering credit monitoring to affected users.

Paragraph 2: With over 40 million monthly visitors, the breach has massive implications for consumer privacy and identity theft risk. ShinyHunters’ targeting of high-traffic consumer platforms highlights their shift toward large-scale data theft for resale on dark web markets. The incident also underscores the growing prevalence of “double extortion” tactics, where attackers threaten to leak data unless ransoms are paid.

breaking_news.title: APT28 Uses Webhook-Based Macros for Covert Data Exfiltration in Europe
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Russia-linked APT28 conducted Operation MacroMaze from September 2025 to January 2026, targeting European entities using webhook-based macro malware. Spear-phishing emails delivered weaponized Word documents containing INCLUDEPICTURE fields pointing to webhook[.]site URLs hosting JPGs. These fields triggered remote payload downloads and established covert C2 channels via legitimate services like GitHub and Pastebin.

Paragraph 2: The campaign highlights APT28’s continued use of living-off-the-land techniques to evade detection and reduce infrastructure footprint. By leveraging widely available services, attackers increase attribution difficulty and operational resilience. Organizations in Western and Central Europe—especially those in government and defense—must prioritize macro security and webhook monitoring.

breaking_news.title: AWS Reports AI-Powered Attack Compromises 600+ FortiGate Firewalls
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Amazon Threat Intelligence revealed a Russian-speaking cybercriminal used commercial generative AI tools to compromise over 600 FortiGate firewalls across 55 countries between January and February 2026. The attacker did not exploit vulnerabilities but abused exposed management ports and weak single-factor credentials—using AI to automate credential stuffing and reconnaissance at scale.

Paragraph 2: This campaign exemplifies how AI is lowering the barrier to entry for large-scale infrastructure attacks. Organizations with internet-facing devices using default or reused credentials are at immediate risk. The attack bypassed perimeter defenses entirely, emphasizing that authentication hygiene and network segmentation are now more critical than ever.

breaking_news.title: SolarWinds Serv-U Critical Flaws Allow Root Access, Patched After Active Exploitation
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: SolarWinds patched four critical vulnerabilities (CVE-2025-40538, CVE-2025-40539, CVE-2025-40540, CVE-2025-40541) in Serv-U file transfer software, all rated CVSS 9.1. One broken access control flaw (CVE-2025-40538) allows authenticated high-privilege users to create system admin accounts and execute arbitrary code as root—potentially enabling full server compromise.

Paragraph 2: Serv-U is widely used across enterprises for secure file transfers, making exploitation highly impactful. Though no active exploitation was confirmed at time of disclosure, the severity and centrality of Serv-U in enterprise data workflows warrant immediate patching. Unpatched deployments risk complete data exfiltration, ransomware deployment, and lateral movement via compromised file servers.

breaking_news.title: Medical Device Maker UFP Technologies Confirms Ransomware Data Theft
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: UFP Technologies, a U.S. manufacturer of medical devices, disclosed a cybersecurity incident involving data theft and file-encrypting malware. The company confirmed that sensitive IT systems were compromised, though specific ransomware family or attack vector remains unconfirmed. The incident has triggered regulatory notifications and internal forensic investigations.

Paragraph 2: As a supplier to healthcare providers, UFP’s breach raises concerns about downstream impact on medical device safety and patient care. Medical device supply chain attacks are increasingly common, with attackers targeting vendors to access sensitive health data or disrupt critical product lines. The incident underscores the need for robust third-party risk management in healthcare ecosystems.

breaking_news.title: Fake Next.js Interview Tests Deploy Backdoor Malware to Developers
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Microsoft Defender Threat Intelligence uncovered a coordinated campaign targeting software developers via malicious Next.js repositories disguised as legitimate coding tests and job interview assessments. The malicious packages, when cloned and opened, execute hidden scripts to steal credentials, install C2 backdoors, and pivot into corporate environments via developer workstations.

Paragraph 2: This supply chain attack exploits trust in open-source repositories and the widespread use of AI-assisted development tools. Developers—especially junior or job-seeking candidates—are high-risk targets due to urgency and reduced security vigilance. The campaign demonstrates how threat actors are shifting focus from infrastructure to human workflows, turning developer tools into initial access vectors.
